description.narrative: Vietnam’s per capita GDP growth since 1990 has been among the fastest in the world.. However, this growth has also generated challenges with regard to environmental degradation. The environmental quality of Vietnam’s air, land, and water has deteriorated considerably.. Despite of a relatively high rate of (informal) solid urban waste recycling, the current economy leads to the depletion of precious resources and does not account for negative externalities exerted upon the environment. A circular economy presents a sustainable solution to part of the socio-economic and environmental challenges Many companies and organizations are familiar with the Cleaner Production principle of ‘Reduce – Reuse – Recycle’. Organizations like the governmental CIEM and the VCCI are interested in the potential of circular economy strategies, and the VCCI has recently initiated a programme on circular economy, involving its VBCSD. A scoping study was commissioned by RVO and executed at the end of 2017 and the beginning of 2018 to identify potential areas of circular (business) cooperation between Vietnam and NL. However, knowledge on circular economy as a concept is not yet fully developed. This means that awareness raising and capacity building on circular approaches will be necessary in order to show its value, to trigger interest and to create public and private actors’ skills to develop and implement circular economy policies, strategies and actions. The envisaged activity will help the Vietnams government to understand hwo circular economy works in different countries all over the world, help them to sharpen their strategy for the complex field of Circular Economy and to provide advise how to set up a Circular Economy Platform, such as the Holland Circular Hotspot.
